ptolemy.backtrack.eclipse.ast

Class TypeAnalyzerState

  • java.lang.Object
    • ptolemy.backtrack.eclipse.ast.TypeAnalyzerState

  • public class TypeAnalyzerState
extends java.lang.Object
    The state of a type analyzer. As the type analyzer traverses an Eclipse Abstract Syntax Tree (AST), it records its state in an object of this class. This state is passed to the handlers that handle special events in the traversal. The handlers may then retrieve information about the current state of the analyzer.
    Since:
    Ptolemy II 5.1
    Version:
    $Id$
    Author:
    Thomas Feng
    Accepted Rating:
    Red (tfeng)
    Proposed Rating:
    Red (tfeng)

      static class  TypeAnalyzerState.CurrentClassElement
      A table to hold the current class, which is the only object in the table.

      • enterClass

        public void enterClass(java.lang.Class c)
        Enter the scope of a class. The current class is set to the class entered and the last current class is pushed to the previous class stack.
        Parameters:
        c - The class entered.
        See Also:
        leaveClass()

      • getCurrentClass

        public java.lang.Class getCurrentClass()
        Get the current class (the class currently being inspected).
        Returns:
        The current class. It may be null when there is no current class.
        See Also:
        setCurrentClass(Class)

      • getPreviousClasses

        public java.util.Stack<java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,java.lang.Class>> getPreviousClasses()
        Get the previous class stack. The previous class stack stores all the entered but not exited class definitions as well as blocks, not including the current class. Each element in the stack is either of type Class or type Hashtable. The bottom element in the stack is always null.

        An element of type Hashtable means the previous entity is a block, where classes can also be defined in it. In that case, simple class names are the keys of the table, and Class objects are its values.

        Returns:
        The previous class stack.
        See Also:
        setPreviousClasses(Stack)

      • getVariable

        public Type getVariable(java.lang.String name)
        Get the type of a variable with its name in the current scope and all the scopes enclosing the current scope. If it is not in the current scope, scopes enclosing the current scope are checked. The scopes can be a variable scope or a class scope. The effect is the same as getVariable(name, false).
        Parameters:
        name - The variable name.
        Returns:
        The type of the variable, or null if it is not found.
        See Also:
        getVariable(String, boolean)

      • getVariable

        public Type getVariable(java.lang.String name,
                        boolean variablesOnly)
        Get the type of a variable with its name in the current scope and all the scopes enclosing the current scope. If it is not in the current scope, scopes enclosing the current scope are checked.

        If variableOnly is true, only variable scopes are checked, but class scopes are ignored.

        Parameters:
        name - The variable name.
        variablesOnly - Whether to check variable scopes only.
        Returns:
        The type of the variable, or null if it is not found.
        See Also:
        getVariable(String)

      • getVariableStack

        public java.util.Stack<java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,Type>> getVariableStack()
        Get the variable stack. The variable stack is a stack of scopes. Each element in this stack is of type Hashtable, with variable names as its keys and types of those variables as its values. The top element in this stack is considered the current scope. Other elements in it are scopes enclosing the current scope.
        Returns:
        The variable stack.
        See Also:
        setVariableStack(Stack)

      • isVariable

        public boolean isVariable(java.lang.String name)
        Return whether a name refers to a variable in the variable stack.
        Parameters:
        name - The name.
        Returns:
        true if the name refers to a defined variable.

      • leaveBlock

        public void leaveBlock()
        Leave a block declaration.
        See Also:
        enterBlock()

      • leaveClass

        public void leaveClass()
        Leave a class declaration. The current class is set back to the last current class (the class on the top of the previous class stack).
        See Also:
        enterClass(Class)

      • nextAnonymousCount

        public int nextAnonymousCount()
        Get the next count of anonymous classes in the current class.
        Returns:
        The count.

      • nextTotalAnonymousCount

        public int nextTotalAnonymousCount()
        Get the next count of total anonymous classes.
        Returns:
        The count.

        Parameters:

      • setPreviousClasses

        public void setPreviousClasses(java.util.Stack<java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,java.lang.Class>> previousClasses)
        Set the previous class stack. The previous class stack stores all the entered but not exited class definitions, not including the current class. Each element in the stack is of type Class. The bottom element in the stack is always null.
        Parameters:
        previousClasses - The previous class stack.
        See Also:
        getPreviousClasses()

      • setVariableStack

        public void setVariableStack(java.util.Stack<java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,Type>> variableStack)
        Set the variable stack. The variable stack is a stack of scopes. Each element in this stack is of type Hashtable, with variable names as its keys and types of those variables as its values. The top element in this stack is considered the current scope. Other elements in it are scopes enclosing the current scope.
        Parameters:
        variableStack - The variable stack.
        See Also:
        getVariableStack()

      • unsetClassScope

        public void unsetClassScope()
        Unset the current scope as a class scope (a scope opened by a class declaration).

        A class scope should be unset when removed from the scope stack.

        See Also:
        setClassScope()
